item.title: Sonos Offloads Beam Soundbar at Record Low, Now Cheaper Than Basic Alternative and Perfect Christmas Gift
item.content:encoded:
Flat-screen TVs are getting thinner and better looking all the time, but this design change means that the sound quality suffers because manufacturers can’t fit good speakers into panels that are only a few millimeters thick. A good soundbar fills this gap by giving your beautiful 4K or OLED display the sound it needs and make movie nights and music listening truly immersive.

The good news is that the Sonos Beam (Gen 2) soundbar is now on sale on Amazon for $369, down from its list price of $499. This is the lowest price ever which makes it a great Christmas gift for yourself or anyone whose TV audio sounds flat and lifeless. This small soundbar works just as well under wall-mounted TVs or on entertainment centers and brings Dolby Atmos spatial audio and multi-room music streaming to living rooms.

See at Amazon

Dolby Atmos

The Beam Gen 2 processes Dolby Atmos audio tracks to make height channels that make sound seem to come from above and around you and adds a vertical dimension to the usual left-right stereo field. This technology for spatial audio makes it sound like helicopters are flying over you, rain is falling from the ceiling, and background noises put you in the scene instead of just in front of it. Psychoacoustic processing and carefully angled drivers that bounce sound off your ceiling make it sound like you have dedicated height speakers without actually installing them.

The Beam’s center channel focuses on voice frequencies to make sure you hear every word without turning up the volume, which is one of the most common complaints about TV audio. With this dedicated dialogue processing, you won’t miss important plot points when people are whispering or need subtitles to understand speech with an accent. When you watch news or dramas with a lot of dialogue, the Speech Enhancement feature in the Sonos app boosts voice frequencies even more. It gives you customizable clarity that works with different types of content.

Trueplay tuning technology uses your iPhone’s microphone to figure out how sound bounces off the walls and other surfaces in your room and then automatically changes the Beam’s output to make up for any problems with the sound. Rooms with hard floors and bare walls that make harsh reflections get tuned differently than rooms with carpet and soft furniture that absorbs sound. This calibration process only takes about two minutes, but it makes the sound much better than using generic soundbar settings that assume the same room acoustics.

To set it up, all you need are two cables: one HDMI eARC cable that goes from your TV to the device and one power cord that goes to an outlet. The soundbar automatically finds your TV and works with your current remote, so you don’t have to switch between controllers or set up universal remotes. With Amazon Alexa, Google Assistant, or Sonos Voice Control, you can change the volume, skip songs, or switch inputs without using a remote. With Apple AirPlay 2 support, you can stream music wirelessly from iPhones, iPads, and Macs.

The Beam Gen 2 is now competitive with mid-range soundbars that don’t have Dolby Atmos or multi-room capabilities because the price dropped from $499 to $369. Anyone who wants to improve their TV’s sound quality beyond the mediocre built-in speakers will get a lot of value from it.

item.title: Dell i7 1TB Laptop Rated 5/5 Stars Drops 73% Off on Amazon, Crashes to All-Time Low With $200 Bonus Pack
item.content:encoded:
Smart shoppers know that paying full price on official brand websites often means leaving hundreds of dollars on the table that could stay in your pocket. A capable laptop doesn’t require a $2,000 investment when strategic shopping reveals the same specs at drastically lower prices through different retailers.

This Dell Inspiron 15″ touchscreen laptop sells for $759 on Amazon right now, marked down from its typical $2,799 price tag, while Dell’s official site shows no such promotion. This is a record low that slashes over $2,000 off a machine featuring a 13th-generation Intel Core i7 processor, 16GB RAM, and a 1TB SSD that handles everything from office work to content creation.

See at Amazon

13th-Gen Intel Core i7 Has Processing Power That Lasts for Years

The Intel Core i7-1355U processor has 10 cores which are split between performance and efficiency cores which lets it handle demanding applications while still having a good battery life. This hybrid architecture gives performance cores to heavy tasks like video rendering or compilation and efficiency cores to light workloads and background processes. The processor can boost up to 5.0 GHz, which gives it the power it needs to run professional software like Adobe Premiere, AutoCAD, or Excel spreadsheets with thousands of rows.

The 15.6-inch Full HD touchscreen is useful in a way that some touch-enabled laptops aren’t. When editing photos, adding notes to documents, or scrolling through long web pages, it feels natural to directly interact with interface elements. The WVA panel doesn’t glare, so you can still see it in bright offices or near windows where shiny screens turn into mirrors. Windows 11’s touch support is better than in previous versions and it has better palm rejection and gesture controls that are more responsive, which makes people more productive instead of annoying them with accidental inputs.

The 85% screen-to-body ratio makes the bezels around the display as small as possible, giving the laptop a modern look and maximizing the amount of screen space within its physical footprint. The wide range of ports, which includes both legacy USB-A ports and modern USB-C ports, fixes one of the most annoying trends in modern laptops. For photographers and videographers who need to transfer footage from their cameras, the SD card reader is a must-have and HDMI 1.4 makes it easy to connect to external monitors without needing dongles.

The Windows 11 Pro edition has business features that the Home edition does not, such as BitLocker encryption, Remote Desktop, and Hyper-V virtualization. This makes this laptop good for workplaces that need extra security. With the Pro license, you also have more control over Windows updates. With Copilot AI integration, Microsoft’s generative AI assistant is built right into the operating system and can help you write, generate code, and provide contextual help without having to switch to other apps or websites.

This i7-powered laptop is now in the same price range as budget Chromebooks and entry-level Windows machines with much worse specs, thanks to a savings of more than $2,000. At this price point, many laptops still come with older i5 processors, 8GB of RAM, and smaller SSDs and this Dell configuration stands out from the rest.

item.title: Amazon Hits Mini PCs Hard, Apple’s Newest Mac Mini at Record Low Price Makes Mid-Range Options Obsolete
item.content:encoded:
Mini PCs are a niche category where lesser-known brands dominate by assembling components into compact machines that prioritize space-saving over brand recognition. Apple’s Mac mini faces virtually no real competition in this segment, and combines iconic industrial design with performance and connectivity that generic mini PCs struggle to match.

The latest Mac mini with M4 chip and 256GB SSD storage currently sells for $479 on Amazon, reduced from its $599 list price, and hits a record low that eclipses the competition just before Christmas. This newest generation shrinks the already-compact form factor down to five by five inches while packing a 10-core CPU and 10-core GPU that outperforms most desktop computers twice its size.

See at Amazon

Desktop Performance

The M4 chip is Apple’s fourth-generation custom silicon and it has a 10-core CPU that is split into performance and efficiency cores which handle demanding tasks and background processes in a smart way. This architecture gives the Mac mini performance that is on par with Intel and AMD desktop processors, but it uses much less power.

This means that the Mac mini can run quietly without the loud fan noise that comes with most desktop towers. The 10-core GPU can handle graphics-heavy tasks like editing photos in Lightroom, editing 4K videos in Final Cut Pro and even playing moderate games through Apple Arcade or native Mac games. Unified memory architecture gives the CPU and GPU 16GB of memory to share and gets rid of the slowdowns that happen when separate graphics cards have to move data back and forth between system RAM.

The new chassis is only five by five inches which is about the same size as a big coffee mug on a desk. It can do the same things that a full-size desktop tower can do. This smaller size makes the Mac mini perfect for minimalist desk setups, small apartments where space is at a premium, or workstations with multiple monitors where tower PCs would take up too much space. The aluminum construction passively dissipates heat while keeping the high quality that Apple products are known for.

Port configuration finally fixes one of the Mac mini’s long-standing problems by adding USB-C ports on the front and a headphone jack that makes it easier to reach around than in previous generations. The front ports make it much easier to connect USB drives, charging cables, or headphones on a daily basis. The back panel still has Thunderbolt 4 ports, HDMI output, and Gigabit Ethernet for permanent connections. Thunderbolt 4 can connect up to three 6K displays or one 8K display and gives creative professionals and productivity users the ability to use more than one monitor at a time.

With Apple Intelligence integration, AI-powered features are built right into the operating system: These features include help with writing, summarizing emails, and organizing photos intelligently without sending data to other servers. This processing on the device keeps your information private while also giving you features like smart replies, automatic transcription, and suggestions based on what you’re doing that help you get more done.

Right now, the M4 Mac mini is now cheaper than many prebuilt Windows desktops that don’t come with a monitor and have worse processors.

item.title: ROG Strix G16 Laptop With RTX 5070, 1TB SSD and Ryzen 9 Hits New Low, Amazon Cuts All Profit Margin
item.content:encoded:
Serious gamers demand hardware that won’t bottleneck their competitive edge or compromise visual fidelity when maxed-out settings matter most. The Asus ROG Strix G16 (2025 edition) targets this exact audience with bleeding-edge components that few laptops currently offer, including the brand-new Nvidia GeForce RTX 5070 GPU powered by Blackwell architecture.

Amazon is offering this powerhouse for $1,699 right now, marked down from its $2,099 list price, hitting a record low just before Christmas arrives. This represents one of the rare gaming laptops shipping with the RTX 5070 and gives early adopters access to DLSS 4 technology and next-generation ray tracing performance that won’t become mainstream for months. The combination of AMD’s latest Ryzen 9 9955HX processor, 32GB of DDR5-5600 RAM, 1TB SSD and a 240Hz display creates a no-compromise gaming machine built for competitive esports and demanding AAA titles.

See at Amazon

Changes the Game for Mobile Gaming

The Nvidia GeForce RTX 5070 is a big step forward in technology and its Blackwell architecture makes ray tracing and AI-powered frame generation through DLSS 4 much better. DLSS 4’s multi-frame generation can make games run three times faster by making up to three AI frames for every traditionally rendered frame and it can effectively triple frame rates in games that support it. Max-Q technologies improve power efficiency without lowering performance which means that the RTX 5070 can deliver desktop-class gaming in a portable form factor that doesn’t use up battery life right away.

The AMD Ryzen 9 9955HX processor has a Zen 5 architecture with a lot of cores and boost clocks that go over 5GHz and gives the CPU the power it needs to keep GPU bottlenecks from happening in competitive games. This processor can handle background tasks like streaming, Discord, and playing music without slowing down games which makes it perfect for content creators who game or streamers who need encoding power. The DDR5-5600 memory runs faster than the DDR4 memory from the previous generation and lowers latency and raises bandwidth for games that use a lot of memory and for multitasking.

The 1TB PCIe Gen 4 SSD loads things so quickly that you only have to wait a few seconds between matches or loading screens. This drive has enough space for your operating system and important apps, as well as modern games like Starfield or Baldur’s Gate 3 that require more than 100GB to install. PCIe Gen 4 speeds can reach up to 7,000MB/s for sequential reads and makes asset streaming smooth and almost completely stops texture pop-in, which is a problem with slower storage solutions.

The ROG Nebula Display has a 2560×1600 resolution and a 16:10 aspect ratio which means it has more vertical screen space than standard 16:9 panels, but it still has the same pixel density needed for clear images. The 240Hz refresh rate and 3ms response time get rid of motion blur and ghosting in fast-paced shooting or racing games where every millisecond counts. The new ACR film technology makes contrast ratios better and glare less, so the display can be used in brighter places without reflections washing out darker scenes.

The Intelligent Cooling system from ROG uses tri-fan technology, a full-width heatsink, and well-placed vents to get rid of heat without making noise like a jet engine. The advanced thermal design keeps the CPU and GPU from getting too hot during long gaming sessions, which would slow down performance if it weren’t for it. Cooler parts also make hardware last longer because high temperatures over time cause parts to wear out faster.

The RTX 5070 laptop is now at a price point where it competes with last-generation RTX 4070 machines that can’t match the Blackwell architecture’s performance improvements. Most gaming laptops with similar specs cost between $2,200 and $2,600, so this Asus deal is very good for cutting-edge hardware.

item.title: Fallout Season 2 Will Start Streaming Early
item.content:encoded:
Less than two years after it debuted, Amazon’s Fallout TV show is back with season 2, and even earlier than originally promised. New episodes will now kick off a whole 24 hours earlier than previously planned. The company used the Las Vegas sphere to reveal the reverse-delay.

Originally set to launch on December 17, 2025, Fallout season 2 will now begin streaming on December 16 at 9:00 p.m. ET instead. New episodes will be released weekly, with the latest batch wrapping up on February 4, 2026. Walton Goggins’ Ghoul, Ella Purnell’s vault dweller, and Brotherhood of Steel squire Aaron Moten will return as the show moves the focus to New Vegas, the subject of the critically acclaimed video game spin-off by Obsidian Entertainment.

Season 2 adds Macaulay Culkin in an unknown role and Justin Theroux as Mr. House, the guy in charge of New Vegas. It’s unclear exactly how Lucy and the Ghoul’s roundtrip through the desert will unfold, but the show has already teased Deathclaws and other big monsters making brief cameos. Will we see some Super Mutants too?

The show seems likely to wade even more deeply into wasteland conspiracies and factional disputes, but none of it will be resolved in the eight upcoming episodes. Amazon has already renewed Fallout for season 3, and probably will make as many more as showrunner Jonathan Nolan is able to give them. Remember, Fallout isn’t on Netflix or HBO. You’ll need a Prime subscription to watch. Or the password to your friend’s account.

item.title: The Outer Worlds 2 Is So Good It Makes The Wait For Fallout 5 That Much Easier
item.content:encoded:
For the last few weeks, I’ve been playing Obsidian Entertainment’s The Outer Worlds 2. I really like it! And after wrapping the game up over the weekend, I realized that I just played the closest thing to Fallout 5 that I’ll get until Bethesda finally ships the wasteland RPG in, like, a decade from now.

The Outer Worlds 2, out now on Xbox, PlayStation, and PC, is the much bigger and better follow-up to Obsidian’s original Outer Worlds from 2016. While both games are open-world space RPGs, the sequel expands on every part of the original game, featuring more planets, weapons, enemies, skills, factions, and features. And like the original, Outer Worlds 2 is clearly inspired by Bethesda’s Fallout games and Obsidian’s own Fallout: New Vegas. The original got close to emulating the experience of playing (and screwing around in) a Fallout RPG, but due to a limited budget and scope, didn’t quite nail it. The Outer Worlds 2 does, and it’s wonderful.

Everything I love about Bethesda’s Fallout games is here. Hand-crafted areas to explore, filled with stretches of empty land, bustling communities, and odd characters and situations to stumble into. The Outer Worlds 2 also features an in-depth RPG system with a massive list of perks and skills to level up, letting you build a smooth-talking scam artist, a beefy melee warrior, or a super-smart sniper able to hack any robot. Or you could create a murderous, evil idiot who is super lucky. And the best part is, like in Fallout 3 and New Vegas, the world reacts to your choices and offers up ways to use those skills and perks to your advantage.

I mean, The Outer Worlds 2 even includes the ability to turn on an in-game radio and listen to in-world music, DJs, ads, and more as you hike about the various planets, completing quests and discovering new locations. This is a key part of the Fallout formula for me and something I was happy to see included in The Outer Worlds 2. Blowing up random enemies with a laser gun is just more fun when retro music is blaring in the background.

And unlike Bethesda’s Fallout games, The Outer Worlds 2 doesn’t feel like it’s falling apart as you continue to play. It also features much better writing, more interesting companions, better combat, and far fewer bugs. In my many, many hours with The Outer Worlds 2, I only had to reload a save due to a bug once, and only encountered one other really annoying game-breaking glitch. Beyond that, The Outer Worlds 2 is a more stable and better-looking spin on the Bethesda RPG formula.

If you’re someone who has been craving a new Fallout and doesn’t want to replay Fallout 3 or New Vegas for the 20th time, I’d highly recommend Outer Worlds 2. It’s probably the closest thing to a Fallout 5 we’ll be getting from an Xbox-owned studio any time soon, because The Elder Scrolls 6 is still likely years away, and the next Fallout will only arrive once Bethesda is done with that. Thankfully, Outer Worlds 2 is pretty dang rad and is highly replayable. A good way to kill a few years while you wait for Fallout 5.
